images.copyright: Eurasian red squirrel in Northumberland, England (© Michael_Conrad/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Eurasian red squirrel
images.desc: Who could resist that squishy face? A Eurasian red squirrel perches on a snowy pine branch, paws clutching a pine cone like it's the last snack on Earth. These little acrobats stay busy collecting nuts, seeds and fungi—feasting on fresh finds in summer and on stored cones through winter.

images.copyright: Medieval Aqueduct, Perugia, Italy (© Sean Pavone/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Medieval Aqueduct, Perugia, Italy
images.desc: In the Italian region of Umbria, Perugia reveals itself slowly, like a page from another era turning in the wind. Its stones carry memories of Etruscans, medieval rulers, artists and generations of students. The city unfolds through steep lanes, mesmerising viewpoints and corners that feel almost painted.

og.title: Medieval Aqueduct, Perugia, Italy
og.desc: In the Italian region of Umbria, Perugia reveals itself slowly, like a page from another era turning in the wind. Its stones carry memories…

images.copyright: Light decorations on Spiegelgracht canal, Amsterdam, Netherlands (© Amith Nag Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Spiegelgracht canal in Amsterdam
images.desc: Have you ever wondered how canals changed the way cities developed? For thousands of years, people have built canals to transport goods, control water flow and connect places. From ancient Mesopotamia and Egypt to medieval Europe, they transformed cities like Venice and Bruges into trade hubs. The Netherlands took this even further—by the 17th century, they were designing waterways that shaped cities such as Amsterdam.

og.title: Spiegelgracht canal in Amsterdam
og.desc: Have you ever wondered how canals changed the way cities developed? For thousands of years, people have built canals to transport goods…

images.copyright: Tufted titmouse perched on pine boughs, Massachusetts, United States (© Tim Laman/NPL/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Tufted titmouse
images.desc: Before you spot it, you'll likely hear it—a series of clear, whistling notes, often described as 'peter-peter-peter,' announcing the presence of the tufted titmouse, featured in today's image. This small, grey songbird, measuring about 15 centimetres in length, is a lively inhabitant of the eastern North America. Unlike other small songbirds, it has a tufted grey crest that crowns its head, giving it a distinctive and expressive look. Despite its small size, the tufted titmouse is surprisingly strong, able to crack open even large seeds with its beak—showcasing its skill and resourcefulness in the daily pursuit of food. It forages both in the trees and on the ground, searching for a varied diet of insects, nuts, seeds, berries and other invertebrates.

og.title: Tufted titmouse
og.desc: Before you spot it, you'll likely hear it—a series of clear, whistling notes, often described as 'peter-peter-peter,' announcing the…

images.copyright: Merced River, Yosemite National Park, California, United States (© Ron and Patty Thomas/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Merced River, Yosemite National Park, California, United States
images.desc: Every masterpiece needs a brushstroke to tie it together. For Yosemite National Park, in the United States, that stroke is the Merced River—painting reflections of granite cliffs, pine forests and waterfalls across its canvas. One of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers, this waterway begins high in the Sierra Nevada. It gathers meltwater and winds 233 kilometres west through Yosemite Valley into California's Central Valley.

og.title: Merced River, Yosemite National Park, California, United States
og.desc: Every masterpiece needs a brushstroke to tie it together. For Yosemite National Park, in the United States, that stroke is the Merced River…

images.title: Info
images.caption: Spotted poinsettia
images.desc: Some plants simply sit quietly on windowsills. The poinsettia? It demands the spotlight. Bright, bold and as red as Rudolph's nose, it is native to Mexico and Central America. In Mexico, it is known as the Flores de Nochebuena (Flowers of the Holy Night), a symbol of Christmas celebrations. The poinsettia's common name comes from Joel Roberts Poinsett, the first United States minister to Mexico, who introduced it to the United States in the 1820s.

og.title: Spotted poinsettia
og.desc: Some plants simply sit quietly on windowsills. The poinsettia? It demands the spotlight. Bright, bold and as red as Rudolph's nose, it is…

images.copyright: The summit of Mount Everest at sunset, seen from Renjo La, Nepal (© shoults/Alamy)
images.title: Info
images.caption: The summit of Mount Everest at sunset, seen from Renjo La, Nepal
images.desc: From the rolling Alps to the towering Himalayas, mountains cover nearly a quarter of Earth's land and host 15% of the world's population and nearly half of its biodiversity hotspots. On the crest of the Great Himalayas of southern Asia, along the border between Nepal and Tibet, stands Mount Everest. At over 8,800 metres, it is the world's highest peak and a symbol of human aspiration and natural beauty. In 1953, Sir Edmund Hillary of New Zealand and Tenzing Norgay, a Nepali Sherpa climber, were the first to successfully reach its summit, marking a historic achievement in exploration. Its glaciers feed rivers sustaining millions, showing that mountains are more than scenery—they are lifelines.

og.title: The summit of Mount Everest at sunset, seen from Renjo La, Nepal

images.copyright: Castle of Rocca Calascio, Abruzzo, Italy (© carlo alberto conti/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Castle of Rocca Calascio, Italy
images.desc: Among the silent crests of the Abruzzo Apennines in Italy, when autumn begins to touch the rocks with amber fingers, the Castle of Rocca Calascio appears like a mirage of stone and wind. At over 1,400 metres above sea level, the fortress has watched over valleys tinged with copper and gold for centuries, suspended between heaven and Earth like an ancient thought.
